review.title: Event Coreference Resolution by Iteratively Unfolding Inter-dependencies among Events
review.abstract: We introduce a novel iterative approach for event coreference resolution that gradually builds event clusters by exploiting inter-dependencies among event mentions within the same chain as well as across event chains. Among event mentions in the same chain, we distinguish within- and cross-document event coreference links by using two distinct pairwise classifiers, trained separately to capture differences in feature distributions of within- and cross-document event clusters. Our event coreference approach alternates between WD and CD clustering and combines arguments from both event clusters after every merge, continuing till no more merge can be made. And then it performs further merging between event chains that are both closely related to a set of other chains of events. Experiments on the ECB+ corpus show that our model outperforms state-of-the-art methods in joint task of WD and CD event coreference resolution.

sections.heading: 3 System Overview and A Worked Example
sections.text: In the first phase, the relationships between the event chains are conducted iteratively, as suggested by pairs of WD and CD merger classifiers. Argumentative characteristics of individual event mentions are propagated within a cluster after each merger process. In the second phase, the relationships between the event chains are examined iteratively. In the third phase, event mentions are carefully generated and further mergers are performed. The example in Figure 1 illustrates the two phases of our proposed approach. It shows two iterations of WD and CD mergers.

sections.heading: 4.1 Document Clustering
sections.text: Our approach begins with a pre-processing step that bundles input documents (D) into a set of document clusters (C) to reduce search space and errors (Lee et al., 2012). In our experiments, we used the affinity propagation algorithm (Buitinck et al., 2013) for tf − idf vectors where terms are only correct nouns and verbs (without report and auxiliary bans) in the document. Although it is interesting to understand the influence of false document clusters on event correferences, this algorithm led to perfect document clusters on the ECB + Dataset benchmark (Cybulska and Vossen, 2014b, a), which is consistent with the previous study (Lee et al., 2012) on the associated ECB datasets (Bejan and Harabagiu CD, 2010) 1, which shows that clustering in the ECB document input algorithm of EM documents algorithm (algorithm C) is algorithmic.

sections.text: Specifically for WD merges, as described in lines 8-10 of Algorithm 1, we iteratively traverse pairs of clusters that contain a pair. The ECB + dataset is an extended version of the ECB dataset. Both datasets contain documents on the same 43 topics within a document, one mention of each cluster. If the similarity value between the two event mentions is above a matched threshold of 0.6 2, we merge the two clusters. Likewise, for CD merges described in lines 13-15 of Algorithm 1, we iteratively go through cluster pairs that contain a pair of cross-document event mentions, and merge the two clusters if the similarity value between the two event mentions is above another tuned threshold of 0.9 3.

sections.heading: 5 Distinguishing WD and CD Merging
sections.text: The first classifier (WD) is used to calculate a similarity between two event mentions within a document and to detect correlated event mention pairs in documents. Both classifiers were implemented as neural networks (Chollet, 2015). The architectures of the two classifiers are shown in Figure 2.WD Classifier: the neural network based on WD Classifier essentially inherits the traits that were effectively demonstrated in previous event reference studies (Ahn, 2006; Chen et al., 2009), including both traits for event words and traits for their arguments. Specifically, the classifier contains a common neural level shared by two event mentions.

sections.heading: 5.1 Characteristics of WD and CD Event Linking
sections.text: In order to better understand the characteristics of linking events within and between documents, we trained two classifiers with the same CD classifier architecture (Figure 2 (b)), but with different groups of event pairs, within documents or cross-document event pairs. We then analyzed the effects of characteristics on each type of event linkage by comparing the learned neural net weights for each characteristic. Table 1 shows comparisons of feature weights. We see that the linkage of events within a document is mainly based on Euclidean distance and cosine similarity values, which are calculated using event word characteristics, with an appropriate amount of weight also assigned to overlapping arguments. However, very low weights were assigned to the similarity and distance values calculated using context embedding. In contrast, the classifiers with cross-doc core event characteristics clearly demonstrated the overlapping similarity and overlapping cosmic features.

sections.heading: 5.2 Neural Net Classifiers and Training
sections.text: In both WD and CD classifiers we use neural network layers with 60 neurons for embedding event word properties and another layer with 1 neuron for embedding argumentation features. In addition, we use an LSTM layer with 30 neurons in the CD classifier for embedding context properties. However, we used 300-dimensional word embedding and a hot 374-dimensional embedding of arguments in all our experiments. Therefore, embedding in the word embedding layer is a 337-dimensional vector and in the LSTM layer 300 * 7-dimensional vectors. We train both classifiers with the ECB + corpus (Cybulska and Vossen, 2014b, a).

sections.text: We are conducting all experiments with the ECB + corpus (Cybulska and Vossen, 2014b, a), which is an extension of the previous data set EventCorefBank (ECB) (Bejan and Harabagiu, 2010). sections.heading: 6.3 Results
sections.text: Table 3 shows the comparison results for both the resolution of event correlations within a document and between documents. In the first stage of iterative merging, the use of two distinct WD and CD classifiers for corresponding WD and CD merges results in significant improvements for both WD and CD event correlation resolution tasks, compared to the use of a common classifier for both types of merges. In addition, the second stage of iterative merging further improves the performance of both WD and CD event correlation resolutions by using the stable interdependence of second-order events. The improvements are consistent when measured using different evaluation metrics of correlation resolution. In addition, our complete model achieved more than 8% improvements over the comparison basis, using the CoNLL F1 score for both WD and CD correlation resolution tasks.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We have presented a new approach to resolving event references that takes full advantage of event interdependencies between second-order event references in the same chain and event references in chains. We also distinguish between second-order event references and CD merges using two different classifiers that capture differences in event correferences in attribute distributions. Our system has proven effective for both WD and CD event references and has surpassed the best event correlation system to date in both tasks. Note that our approach is flexible to incorporate different strategies for performing WD and CD merges. In the future, we plan to further explore the different features of WD and CD-related event references in order to further improve performance of events.
